title: Why are saxophones and brass instruments often referred to as horns? - Quora

response.answer_text: When I think of Horns, the first thing that comes to my mind is a French Horn, or anything with Horn in its name. I don’t think of Saxophones as horns because they are in the woodwind family. And I don’t think of Trumpets and Trombones as horns because they don’t contain the word Horn in their names. When people say horns they usually mean Saxophones, Trumpets, and Trombones. But that tends to confuse me, because as I mentioned, it makes me think of French Horns, Hunting Horns, or any other instrument with horn in their names. I personally prefer just saying “Saxophones and Brass Instruments” because it consists of various brass instruments, along with Saxophones which are made of brass but categorised as woodwind instruments because they have reeds and are built to resemble woodwind instruments apart from the shape of their bells.

Because they are conical shaped instruments. And the first such instruments was made of horns. Literal horns. Like the ones in movies and the Bible. Eventually people made them out of metal, made them long to achieve certain pitches, wrapped them around for compactness, and added keys for chromaticity. In the case of the saxophone, instead of an opening, they stuck a reed in there. That makes it still a horn, but also a woodwind instrument.
